narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Through this course, I was able to continue exploring the themes discussed in Race, Politics, and the Law, think further about the alternative futures created by reconstitutions of learning and thinking through anti-racist work, and gain experience in curriculum development practices.

Further developed a structural analysis of race and white supremacy in the United States. Deeply engaged with the work of a variety of thinkers on antiracism and liberation, with a particular focus on the Black Radical Tradition.
I learned a lot about the different practices and theories of anti-racism and freedom both historically and in the present. I developed analytical skills and writing skills.
I learned a lot about the history of anti-racist movements and ideologies, as well as pedagogical and activist practices to better address social justice and histories of exploitation.

During this class, we built upon our discussions in RPL and expanded upon notions of liberation and freedom that go beyond neoliberal policies and practices of anti-racism and racial justice. We discussed very contemporary issues and linked them back to important works in critical race theory.

This upper-level seminar endows students with a powerful understanding of how antiracist politics are in service to or curtail the procurement of freedom. It considers Black radicalism and Indigenous epistemologies to arrive there. Through the amazing syllabus and Prof HoSang's insightful openings and structure to seminar, it allows you to powerfully articulate nuanced critiques of systems of power as well as robustly understand resistance against those systems. I learned how to more actively listen to my peers through enrollment in this course and how to read more purposefully.

We had a more intensive study of Antiracism and racial justice. We had a great reading list but had to read a book or so every week. In addition to that, every other week we had a group project with our assigned group.
This course was very helpful in seeing the day-to-day, on-the-ground application of anti-racism.

I learned a lot about different forms of activism as well as various forms of ways people are resisting injustice and working toward freedom every day. I gained a lot of insight about my role in academia and how some treat the line between academics and activism.

This course was very enlightening for my understanding of the intersection between anti-racism work and capitalism, and the way that neoliberalism limits real social justice outcomes. My understanding of what true anti-racist work strives towards was strengthened through this course - by HoSang's lectures, by the assigned readings and authors, and by my discussions with the TAs and my peers. I really appreciate how much I learned from this class!

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor HoSang and the two TFs, Alison and Sylvia, were great discussion leaders who pushed our learning in new ways and combined several different modes of thought to think through alternative futures of resistance. I didn't really like the many additional small assignments and class preparation that got tacked onto the class, which sometimes, I thought, helped to facilitate learning and sometimes did not.

The readings were challenging, engaging, and exciting. Dr. HoSang, Alison, and Sylvia were clearly committed to the course and worked really hard to ensure our learning. Seminar discussion was also typically really exciting and illuminating. The first half of the course did feel a bit disorganized in terms of the auxiliary assignments, which were about the workload of a discussion post, but different every week and only announced during or after seminar. In the second half, these assignments were on a rotation among project groups, which worked much better.

Professor HoSang and the teaching fellows were AMAZING. The way class was organized every week was so conducive to online learning and very engaging. I haven't had an online class yet that was as organized and well thought out as this one.

A major strength of this course is the content. The readings and the discussions we had were incredibly important and engaging. Also, everyone in the course, from the students to the instructors, had a visible passion about these issues. However, one weakness is that I don't think the expectations were adequately reflecting the pandemic. I would have liked to have seen more accommodating policies when students were clearly struggling.

The readings in this course were definitely a strength, especially the weeks we could choose our own reading. Also, this class was helpful in discussing what "neoliberalism" means and how this relates to current work on anti-racism. Additionally, the most interesting insight of this class was the work we did on class and labor organizing. However, sometimes it felt as though the syllabus was a bit broad, and potentially just felt like a course addressing all the things left out of RPL. Also, given how difficult and trying this semester was on students and professors alike, it was really hard to keep up with the demand of this class. It often felt as though a new component of participation was added every two weeks and it became overwhelming. It was hard to feel supported by the teaching staff, as the workload and the demand of the course was far too great for most students to bear in a healthy way, which I think detracted from the course. It was hard to stay engaged when completing the readings and pre-class assignments were so draining, or when you had to worry about one or more aspects of participation while in class. I think readjusting the workload is necessary. Also, restating the objectives of the class - especially since two of the listed goals on the syllabus are in relation to assignments. It would help to have clear objectives for learnings/teachings/practices that are to emerge from the class. Hopefully this would make the class feel a bit more focused and less like an extension of RPL.
Strengths: all of it! weaknesses: n/a

Professor HoSang and the teaching assistants tried to be thoughtful about the way this class was carried out. They did make an effort to ensure that the workload was not excessive.  Reading was kept to around one hundred pages per week, and our weekly assignments usually consisted of a reading response or being responsible for a section of the class. The class largely revolved around two assignments: one to design a curriculum unit and the other being a somewhat open-ended final paper. These were probably the highlights of the class, as we were given the freedom to focus on a topic of our choice. The teaching staff were quite thoughtful about pairing us with other students with similar interests, and did offer quite a bit of support for both of these projects. 

I will admit that this course fell short of my expectations. I was quite excited to take another class with Professor HoSang, having previously taken Race, Politics, and the Law. Knowing that Professor HoSang is a stellar instructor, many of the shortcomings of the class can probably be attributed to it being conducted via Zoom. 

Nevertheless, the class itself was structured quite strangely. For one, there were, in my opinion, too many students in the class to allow for any type of substantive discussion. While the teaching assistants did put in quite a bit of effort into the class, it often felt like they ran much of the discussion, making a bit harder to engage with Professor HoSang directly. The workload was also distributed quite poorly, and piled onto the last few weeks of classes. This proved to be slightly stressful, as we essentially spent most of the semester having little to no feedback on our progress. Class discussions were also arranged ahead of time (i.e. who was speaking). While this was helpful in allowing us to focus on a specific part of the reading, sometimes we would be asked to speak at length on a reading two days before class. This was a bit frustrating, and I feel like it would have been better to have free-flowing discussions instead of imposing an excessive amount of structure.  While it was not downright terrible, the organization of the class could have been much better. Thematically, it often felt like our takeaways from each week did not vary much, and the insights I took away from this class pale in comparison to those from Race, Politics, and the Law.

This is a very high workload course! In the middle of a pandemic, students were expected to read hundreds of pages a week, collaborate on assignments, and produce reports for next week's class as well as make discussion posts on canvas. As interesting as the material is, it is very hard to absorb so much of it at once and also meet the high expectations that the course has for its students.

Many of the readings for the course were very interesting and informative. However, given how much we were reading, we often didn't have enough time in class to fully discuss and unpack the readings and how they related to the greater course of study. This was particularly a problem for readings that were more difficult to understand.
I think at times the course was overwhelming but it may have just been the pandemic situation.

Strengths: The books we were assigned throughout the course were fantastic, and provided many different perspectives to the topics of the course. 

Weaknesses: There did not seem to be much room for nuance or critiques of the ideas presented in the course. Sometimes the material was presented as this is what it is and dissenting opinions/perspectives were considered incorrect. These topics are not hard sciences... they are up for debate/critique.

I loved all of the different and unique ways that we were called upon to engage in the course. Another big strength was the syllabus. All of the readings were truly amazing and very engaging. However, sometimes it was difficult to keep up with the rotating tasks that we were assigned for each week as the format of the class seemed to change often. Additionally, the reading load in a couple of weeks was hard to manage. That being said though, overall the class was very beneficial to my learning.

I think a strength was that everyone in the class had taken "Race, Politics, and the Law" which allowed us to start the class with a level of common ground and shared understanding and commitment to the content of the course. However, I think that the size of the class was maybe too large, because it sometimes made in-depth full class discussions difficult. Because of this, the class sometimes felt more like a lecture-seminar hybrid than a pure seminar, because we did not have that much time for discussion (about 20-30 minutes total within every 2 hour class). However, I think that the breakout room conversations were very successful, and gave us the opportunity to really  work with the material and learn from our peers. I learned a lot during the breakout rooms!

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Although a bigger seminar, breaking up into small groups for discussion helped to facilitate student learning and allowed us to think through our peers' ideas and learn from them.
Seminar transitioned well to digital format, and appreciated the smaller breakout rooms for closer discussion.

I think the breakout rooms were used really well to break up the class and foster a lot of different formats of discussion. However, as I said above, I think they could have been a little more realistic about adjusting to student's diminished capacities during covid and the election especially.

Active seminars where we are constantly engaged are very helpful. Also, breakout rooms with guided discussion were the most fruitful (especially when one of the teaching staff was present to help guide the conversation).
I would recommend limiting the use of breakout rooms.

There should be less readings and a lower workload to accommodate for the pandemic. Many students could not always make class due to personal emergencies, but were still expected to produce output for the sake of a grade. This is unfair for students juggling multiple classes amidst a pandemic.
I thought each class had a very good schedule and every minute counted but at times it could be overwhelming

-Breakout rooms were great for discussion 
-There were a lot of mini assignments which were better than having to write longer essays throughout the term, but still ended up being a little overwhelming.

I think that the way in which the created an engaging platform on a virtual platform was a great success. However, the uncertainty of the format for each class was sometimes stress-inducing. I think a balance between a kind of consistency while still occasionally changing things up would be helpful.

I thought that the use of Canvas "Pages" forum was really smart. I had never used Pages in a class before, and I thought it was an excellent way of keeping track of class notes that consolidated all of the most important insights and takeaways from each week.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course to another student because of the lessons I learned about anti-racist organizing, education, and practices. I would be sure to tell another student that there are lots of additional small assignments that are added throughout the term (or at least the first part of it), which definitely adds to the workload.

Yes! If you have some foundation in CRT (like Race Politics and Law provided) this course is a wonderful opportunity to engage with the Black Radical Tradition in greater depth and complexity. Dr. HoSang is brilliant, dedicated, and thorough, as were the TFs, but the highlight of this course was getting to known the community of other students in it, all of whom were passionate, insightful, and caring.
Yes definitely. I learned so much from Professor HoSang and the teaching fellows, but also from my fellow classmates. There was a lot of engaging discussions and very powerful readings.
If you are interested in histories and practices of social justice and anti-racism, take this course. However, be prepared for an intense class that might be difficult for your circumstances.

If you are interested in engaging with the readings on the syllabus then yes. I'm not sure if there are any concrete objectives that we really accomplished other than broadly nuancing what liberation means through the lens of critical race theory. Also, be prepared for a very heavy workload - I would not recommend this class if you are already taking other reading intensive seminars. This is an interesting class  to get a broad scope of liberation.

yes yes yes yes yes! This a reading heavy course and one that requires much attention but it's all worth it! From building curriculum units for RPL to developing senior thesis prospectuses/annotated bibliographies/ & lit reviews, this course shouldn't be passed up!
I would recommend this course to another student if it conducted in-person. Had it been structured slightly differently, this class could have had the potential to be much better.

I would not recommend this course in its current format. The topics and readings are very interesting, but the workload is just too high to be sustainable as is. The quality of the readings were compromised by the quantity of the readings.

I would not recommend this course to a student looking to take a more advanced course in ethnic and anti-racist studies. Personally, I felt like I did not learn many new things throughout the course of the semester.
I would but I would make sure they know that the course was a lot of work but well worth it to learn with great TAs, a great professor and great students.
Before I recommend this course, I think there has to be a serious consideration if the ways anti-Blackness can rear its head in ER&M academic spaces.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. Professor HoSang is absolutely wonderful and very intentional with how he approaches the class material. I learned so much from the readings and the guest speakers that we got to hear from. Additionally, the TFs for the course were outstanding.

I would recommend this class to another student, because I think that it is really important for anyone who has a passion/interest in social justice to push yourself to really think about the theories behind anti-racism work and its even some of its shortcomings in practice. The readings that Professor HoSang chooses for his classes stay with you for a long time and, speaking from my own experience, you continue to learn from even semesters later as you reflect on new things you learn in other classes and in your daily interactions with society.
